I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed $1.3 million capacity development technical assistance (TA) is designed 
to  complement  the  $3.0  million  equity  investment  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
supporting the $14.8 million expansion plan of Mountain Hazelnut Venture Private Limited 
(MHV)—a  company  engaged  in  promoting  hazelnut  production  by  smallholder  farmers  in 
Bhutan since 2010.1 ADB’s equity investment was approved on 11 June 2015.2 
 
2.  The TA will target farmers as the primary beneficiaries of assistance. While ADB’s equity 
investment is mainly focused on ensuring commercial success of the company, the TA will 
ensure that smallholder farmers (particularly women) are better prepared to cope with the 
negative consequences of climate change and fully benefit from their inclusion in the hazelnut 
value chain. Bhutanese farmers are particularly vulnerable to the consequences of climate 
change  (e.g., drought,  floods,  and  landslides).  The  TA  will  provide  training  and  pilot  test 
affordable technologies to increase the climate resilience of the 15,000 smallholder farmers to 
be engaged in the hazelnut value chain being developed by MHV. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Climate change in Bhutan. By 2100, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change 
estimates that South Asian countries, including Bhutan, will experience an increase in average 
temperatures—with rises in daily minimum and maximum temperatures—mostly taking place at 
higher altitudes. A 5% decrease in precipitation is expected during the dry season, and an 11% 
increase is projected during the wet season in the long term.3 
 
4.  Water stress. Decreased precipitation during the dry season, caused by climate change 
and lack of water management resources, will continue to result in water shortages in rural 
farms.4 This will affect both agricultural yields and the quality of crops. As such, water shortage 
is a major cause of food insecurity. Climate adaptation strategies to address the risk of water 
shortage include the development of drought-resistant crops, rainwater harvesting, and efficient 
irrigation methods (such as drip and sprinkler irrigation footnote 3). 
 
5.  Landslides. Higher temperatures will increase the risk of glacial lake outburst floods and 
increased precipitation during the wet season will cause more floods. Floods typically lead to 
landslides, given Bhutan’s steep geographic terrain. With the exception of a few wide valleys, 
agricultural lands in most parts are located on slopes. Assessment indicates that 31% of the 
agriculture land is located on slopes of more than 50 degrees, which are particularly prone to 
landslides (footnote 4). Landslides have a devastating effect on farmers’ livelihoods, as they 
commonly result in the loss of standing crops, but can also prevent access to land for years. 
Sloping agriculture land crops and technology can address the increased risk of landslides 
caused by climate change (footnote 3).  
 
6.  Changes in agroclimatic conditions. Climate change also poses the risks of change in 
crop diversity, delayed sowing with shifting seasons, loss of soil fertility because of erosion and 
loss of nutrients owing to seepage, and increased risk from existing and new diseases and

7.  Impacts on hazelnut farmers. Hazelnut is a climate-resilient crop, as it needs less 
water than annual crops. MHV will help farmers plant trees on degraded or fallow land, thus 
contributing to soil retention (reduced risk of landslides) and watershed stability (reduced risk of 
flooding).  Hazelnut,  however,  is  also  exposed  to  climate  change.  Milder  winters  lower  the 
number of chill hours accumulated, and are predicted to have a negative effect on hazelnut 
yields, in addition to the negative impact of water stress.5 The TA will increase farmers’ climate 
resilience at each step of the value chain through (i) improved irrigation and water storage, 
(ii) integrated  pest  management,  (iii)  improved  harvest  and  post-harvest  management, 
(iv) improved  access  to  information  through  smartphone  applications,  (v)  sharing  of  best 
practices  among  farmers,  (vi)  introduction  of  microclimate  adaptation  strategies,  and 
(vii) research and development into new crop varieties (Table). 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
8.  The TA shares the same impacts as the equity investment project: (i) agriculture gross 
domestic  product  and  exports  boosted,  (ii)  private  sector  agribusiness  developed,  and 
(iii) poverty reduced in dzongkhags (districts) with poverty levels above the national average. 
The outcome will be production of hazelnuts by smallholder farmers based on climate-resilient 
farming practices ramped up.6  
 
9.  The TA and the equity investment project are consistent with several of the performance 
indicators  for  climate  adaptation  projects  included  in  the  Contribution  Arrangement  for  the 
Canadian Climate Fund for the Private Sector in Asia (which will be funding the TA):7 
(i)  Private sector investment addressing an identified vulnerability to climate 
change. MHV will invest $14.8 million in climate-resilient hazelnut trees that will 
be handed over to 15,000 smallholder farmers for free, and farmers will invest in 
equipment to grow and harvest the trees. 
(ii)  Number  of  hectares  of  land  under  climate-resilient  conservation, 
rehabilitation, or sustainable management. Hazelnut trees will be planted on 
at least 6,500 hectares of previously fallow or degraded land.  
(iii)  Number of communities and farmers with access to improved information 
to make climate-resilient choices in agriculture. Training in climate-resilient 
farming practices will be provided to at least 11,000 farmers and information 
sharing through farmer-instructors will be supported in at least 400 communities.   
Please refer to the different TA output indicators in the Table and in the design 
and monitoring framework of the TA (Appendix 1). 
(iv)  Number of employees (gender-disaggregated) employed. MHV’s workforce 
will increase from 500 in 2014 to 1,000 in 2020, including at least 50% women.

C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,300,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Canadian  Climate  Fund  for  the  Private  Sector  in  Asia  under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing 
Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. MHV will provide in-kind contributions in the form 
of staff time, domestic transportation, office and housing accommodation, and other in-kind 
contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  MHV will be the recipient of the TA. MHV is best positioned to coordinate the work of the 
consulting firm and share learning with farmers, the government, and other stakeholders in 
Bhutan. Because of MHV’s contract farming model, the company has a direct relationship with 
farmers and will ensure that they fully benefit from the TA. The interests of MHV and the farmers 
are completely aligned in relation to the TA outcome, since MHV needs a sustainable supply of 
quality hazelnuts. In addition, MHV has the financial capacity to provide the required in-kind 
contributions and ensure successful implementation of the TA. By the end of 2014, MHV’s 
shareholders had invested $10.7 million in the company. With this investment, MHV had helped 
about 5,000 smallholder farmers plant 2.5 million hazelnut trees. ADB’s $3.0 million equity 
investment is part of the company’s $14.8 million expansion plan that will enable it to reach 
15,000 farmers and 10 million trees.8  
 
13.  MHV and ADB have agreed to the terms of a draft TA implementation agreement. The 
draft agreement sets out the outcome and outputs of the TA, the amount of financing to be 
provided by ADB, the terms of reference of the consulting firm to be appointed, the proposed 
budget, and a realistic implementation timetable. 
 
14.  The TA will be carried out by a consulting firm to be recruited in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). For efficiency, the 
consulting firm  is  expected to  bid for  the  entire  package  of  consulting services  required.9 
Quality-  and  cost-based  selection  will  be  used,  with  80:20  weighting,  and  a  full  technical 
proposal. Advance action for the recruitment of the consulting firm will be taken. 
 
15.  The consulting firm will be in charge of procuring the equipment required for the TA. The 
type of equipment for each output is in Appendix 2. Given the small size of each equipment 
package (less than $100,000), the method of procurement will be shopping (as opposed to 
international or national competitive bidding). The consulting firm will be required to receive 
quotes from at least three different suppliers preapproved by ADB and MHV for each type of 
equipment. Upon TA completion, the equipment will be turned over to its users (either MHV or 
the farmers). 
 
16.  ADB and MHV will form a TA task force comprising representatives from ADB and MHV, 
as well as staff from the consulting firm to be hired. The task force will meet regularly to assess 
the progress of the assistance. All disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The TA is expected to start in July 2016 and be completed by June 2019.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,300,000 to Mountain 
Hazelnut Venture Private Limited to be financed on a grant basis by the Canadian Climate Fund 
for the Private Sector in Asia under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility for the 
Climate-Resilient Hazelnut Value Chain in Bhutan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Output 1: Affordable water storage and irrigation solutions designed and pilot 
tested. Farmers in Bhutan on south-facing slopes and in areas affected by rain shadows are 
prone to periods of moisture stress and drought-like conditions. Villages in such areas already 
face challenges securing sufficient drinking water during certain months of the year. Climate 
change is predicted to increase mean average temperatures; it will lead to higher temperature 
peaks as well as milder winters. Precipitation patterns are also predicted to become more erratic, 
with later arrival of rains, geographical shifts in rainfall distribution, and drier winters.1 Drier 
warmer winters will increase water stress in hazelnut orchards, leading to slower establishment 
and reduced crop yields, mainly as a result of ineffective flowering and pollination.2 The design 
and pilot testing of affordable water storage and capture and irrigation solutions will increase the 
resilience of farming communities to drought, and increase the productivity of hazelnut orchards 
and farming lands more generally. 
 
2.  Output 1 will be delivered by the following consultants:  
(i)  Design engineer (international, 6 person-months). The design engineer will be 
responsible for the technical development of mechanisms and devices for water 
capture, water storage, and field irrigation. 
(ii)  Business consultant (international, 6 person-months). The business consultant 
will work on optimizing the economic efficacy of the water collection, storage, and 
irrigation mechanisms—helping to create replicable, efficient systems. 
(iii)  Professional  outreach  trainer (regional, 6 person-months, intermittent). The 
professional outreach trainer will be in charge of transferring all best practices 
and knowledge to hazelnut growers to optimize their harvest. 
(iv)  Irrigation  technician  (regional,  4  person-months,  intermittent).  The  irrigation 
technician will be in charge of transferring knowledge on best practices for the 
operation and maintenance of small-scale irrigation schemes to hazelnut growers. 
 
3.  Output 1 key activities in the terms of reference (TOR) will include assessing needs, 
selecting and/or designing solutions for water storage and collection and irrigation, developing 
training  materials  and  implementing  training  for  farmers  and  extension  staff  of  Mountain 
Hazelnut Venture Private Limited (MHV) in the construction and operation of selected systems, 
and performing follow-up monitoring and evaluation. 
 
4.  Output  2:  Training  in  integrated  pest  management  delivered.  Integrated  pest 
management (IPM) techniques are generally poorly understood by farmers in Bhutan. Besides, 
hazelnut is a new crop and some pests have yet to emerge. Farmers need to adapt their IPM 
strategies to the evolving pest threat caused by climate change. Outbreak of pests and diseases 
in the fields and storage facilities where they were previously unknown has been identified as 
one of the climate change vulnerabilities of Bhutan’s agriculture sector (footnote 1). Farmer 
training programs in hazelnut IPM techniques will enable new techniques to be adopted more 
rapidly, allow more sustainable pest management, and increase yields and nut quality while 
minimizing unnecessary environmental impacts. 
 
5.  Output 2 will be delivered by the following consultants: 
(i)  Plant pathologist (international, 3 person-months). The plant pathologist will be 
responsible for developing IPM strategies suitable for hazelnut growers in Bhutan.

6.  Output 2 key activities in the TOR will include designing and refining IPM programs, 
including an assessment of the economic risk of pests; training hazelnut farmers, monitors, and 
extension agents in IPM; designing new strategies to maximize minimal resources, and in the 
complementary  role  of  pesticides  to  traditional  practices;  and  preparing  training  materials 
suitable for farmers of all genders and levels of literacy that describe practical IPM measures 
and actions for hazelnut orchards. The team will build IPM capacity by sharing best practices 
and learning with the Ministry of Agriculture and Forests and Bhutan’s National Plant Protection 
Centre, and local agriculture extension agents. 
 
7.  Output 3: Technical assistance and training in harvest and post-harvest solutions 
provided.  Hazelnuts  are  a  new  crop  for  Bhutanese  farmers,  and  no  farmers  have  any 
harvesting experience with this crop. Technical assistance (TA) and training for farmers and 
communities will reduce post-harvest losses, improve quality, and develop labor-saving tools 
and methods from harvest through to delivery at a collection center. Such outputs will increase 
the  quantity  of  saleable  nuts,  increase  farmer  incomes,  and  improve  overall  value  chain 
efficiency. More unpredictable and off-season rains caused by climate change require faster 
harvesting, and technologies need to be put in place to protect harvested nuts from the rain 
(humidity increases the risk of bacterial contamination). The TA will provide training and pilot 
technologies to help farmers save time, meet MHV quality standards, and prepare to cope with 
weather risks. 
 
8.  Output 3 will be delivered by the following consultants: 
(i)  Design engineer (international, 6 person-months). The design engineer will be 
responsible for the technical development of drying and de-husking mechanisms 
as well as village and farm storage mechanisms. 
(ii)  Business consultant (international, 6 person-months). The business consultant 
will  work  on  optimizing  the  economic  efficacy  of  drying  and  de-husking 
mechanisms as well as village and farm storage mechanisms—helping to create 
replicable, efficient machines. 
(iii)  Professional  outreach  trainer (regional, 5 person-months, intermittent). The 
professional outreach trainer will be in charge of transferring all best practices 
and knowledge to hazelnut growers to optimize their harvest. 
 
9.  Output 3 key activities in the TOR will include designing affordable harvest and post-
harvest solutions for hazelnut growers, including village and farm storage solutions, prototyping, 
pilot demonstrations, and training for solutions with farmers. 
 
10.  Output  4:  Smartphone  applications  to  improve  farmers’  access  to  extension 
advice  developed. With the help of external consultants, MHV has developed a scalable 
remote management and traceability (RMT) system for its extension service, using a collection 
of  open  source  tools.  Building  on  this  to  develop  a  dedicated,  functional,  user-friendly 
application to be accessed by extension agents and farmers would improve farmers’ ability to 
receive  real-time  extension  advice,  weather  reports,  and  other  information.  Such  a  tool, 
combined with support from extension agents, would give farmers access to technical advice

and  information  to  improve  orchard  management,  yields,  and  incomes;  and  provide  more 
informed  climate  change  adaption  strategies.  The  applications  would  also  be  generally 
applicable as a modular, portable system for other agriculture projects, in the public and private 
sectors, both in Bhutan and worldwide. Bhutan has 3G3 coverage in 26 towns spread across the 
entire project area. For rural areas, MHV estimates that 80% of households in the project area 
have mobile phone coverage, which includes reasonable EDGE4 data connections at up to 128 
kilobits per second. The current smartphone-based tools used by extension agents (which the 
TA is proposed to upgrade) are designed to work with slower rural data connections. The 
software tools remain fully functional offline and are designed to optimize data transfers through 
periodic syncing, incremental updates, and data compression. From 2015 to 2018, the 3G 
network will be expanded in Bhutan to cover all population centers. The EDGE connections will 
also be expanded to cover more than 95% of rural households.

13.  Output 5: Farmer-to-farmer best practice exchanges facilitated. Farmers living in 
scattered remote locations, with limited connectivity, have few opportunities to learn from their 
peers or learn best practices in the field. Hazelnuts are a new crop in Bhutan, so they cannot 
draw upon a local knowledge base. Facilitating farmer-to-farmer best practice exchanges is 
critical to speeding up the adaptation of the company’s innovation and guidance, which will 
improve orchard management, yields, and, by extension, farmers’ incomes. Such practices will 
also aid in transferring climate change adaptation strategies. MHV has a professional extension 
network but, with additional investment and training, its impact could be magnified, and best 
practices more rapidly adopted, shared, and made more inclusive.

16.  Output 6: Climate station network to improve adaptation strategies expanded. In 
addition to the negative impacts on water availability and pollination affecting crop yield, climate 
change could lead to increased harvesting and post-harvest costs as a result of higher and 
more intense rainfall in the harvesting season. Harvest timings could also shift because of 
earlier flowering, faster accumulation of heat units, and increased precipitation. Such changes 
could have significant consequences for harvest and logistical planning. Additionally, because of 
its topography, Bhutan has a multitude of microclimates which are poorly understood. Even less 
well  understood  are  the  possible  effects  of  climate  change  on  these  microclimates.  More 
detailed climate data on these microclimates from an expanded climate monitoring network 
would enable improved variety selection and climate change adaptation. More granular climate 
data would also enable analytical techniques, such as predictive yield models, to be developed 
for hazelnuts. This will aid harvest planning and logistics, and improve the efficiency and climate 
resilience of the hazelnut value chain. Improvement to the weather forecasting network and 
farmer advisory system was identified as an area that could assist farmer production decisions 
in Bhutan and which is a current constraint to climate change adaptation (footnote 1).

19.  Output 7: Capacity for selective breeding programs for climate resilience built. 
MHV has selected hazelnut varieties that thrive in most environmental conditions and have 
been used before as low-risk choices to plant in new areas. Climate change, however, could 
necessitate developing new varieties. Hazelnut requires about 1,000 chill hours in the winter 
months to trigger effective flowering and pollination. Climate change-induced milder winters will 
accumulate fewer chill hours, which is predicted to have a negative effect on hazelnut yields, in 
addition to the negative impact of water stress.5 Capacity building in MHV’s nascent selective 
breeding and in-country multiplication programs from hazelnut selective breeding experts will 
enable climate-resilient varieties (i.e., drought-tolerant, with a lower chill hour requirement) to be 
developed. Improved varieties would also enable Bhutan’s wide range of microclimate niches to 
be filled more effectively. These would be distributed to farmers to optimize the yields and 
farmer incomes, and expand the planting area range (higher and lower altitudes). This will 
extend the positive outcomes to a greater number of farmers and increase climate change 
adaptive capacity for the hazelnut value chain.
